content:
A quando risale l'ultimo backup di cui disponi?

Se non hai un backup prova queste operazioni (ma non è detto che risolvano):

  1. Fare un backup integrale del profilo -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo
  2. Compattare le cartelle -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/compattazione-cartelle
  3. Riavviare Thunderbird
  4. Se il problema non è risolto, ricostruire l'indice globale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/ricostruzione-indice-globale
  5. Riavviare Thunderbird
  6. Se il problema non si è ancora risolto: click destro sulla cartella che contiene la mail illeggibile -> Proprietà -> [Ripara la cartella]

~

For english support -> https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/

content: First, the technical implications are beyond thunderbird and, therefore, beyond me. I offer the following as general information of possible use. Here is more info on error 550 5.5.1: https://blog.warmy.io/blog/how-to-fix-smtp-email-error-550-5-1-1-solved/ this indicates that the receiving email address does not exist. BUT, if you know that it does, then notice comment about check SMTP server. Since you appear to have a web-hosted email, it is not uncommon for such accounts to have errors in server setup. These are settings that can only be adjusted by the email host, not thunderbird. I ran a quick test and found these results: https://mxtoolbox.com/emailhealth/cpanel9.c.fozzy.com/ BUT, I am NOT qualified to assess these results. A person with more knowledge of server configurations may be needed, and fozzy.com can review this with you.

content:
You provided no details, so I will assume you use Windows. Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content: I received the email. The PDF is attached, and is not showing inline. The understandable confusion is that the content of the email is similar to the content of the PDF. I verified this by viewing the source of the message's complex HTML, viewing the message in plain text, and viewing the message after deleting the PDF as I wanted to do due diligence to your request. I doubt your request will ever be done because PDFs are complex and never intended to be processed this way. PDFs are intended to preserve a specific format and font, which would be difficult to reconstruct. Anyway, I was glad to review this for you. :)

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key

content:
Hi David,

While some of your info is helpful, I have more specific questions. The old pc is not accessible, but I do have the hard drive which contains all the Thunderbird profile files, and I can connect this drive to my new pc which has not yet arrived. The old pc was running windows 10, and the new one will be running windows 11.

The laptop I tried to do the import with initially is also running windows 11, and it did not seem that the user app data is in the same place as in windows 10. Also, when I tried installing Thunderbird on the laptop, it took me to the Microsoft store to download it as an app. Is that something I should avoid? Should I be downloading the install file directly from Mozilla for my new machine? Once I have this resolved I will attempt to manually copy the old pc profile to the new instance of Thunderbird and hopefully that will work. Please let me know if you have any insights. Thanks, Gary
creator: gary210

content:
Do NOT install from Microsoft. It's safe, no viruses, but it installs to a different location. That means getting help here on the forum is a problem, and some thunderbird tools, such as troubleshootinginformation do not work. If the version on old pc is not at the appdata\roamiing\thunderbird location, then it also was probably an MS installation. If you have trouble, look for a small text file named profiles.ini, which shows the name of the active profile. Once you have that, here are suggested steps:

  1. install thunderbird from thunderbird.net, start it, and then exit
  2. copy the profile to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles
  3. on windows desktop, click windows key and 'r'. at that small window, enter thunderbird.exe -p and press enter. that starts the profile manager
  4. on that menu,
    • click the 'create profile button,
    • then click Next,
    • then enter a short name, such as OLDPROFILE,
    • then click the choose button and select the profile you just copied in,
    • click finish and when the profile manager menu reappears, it will probably have box checked to use that profile as default when thunderbird is started.
  5. and you're done. :)
creator: davidsk

content: That worked like a charm. Thanks!!
